content.description:
Snack Size is short and sweet. It has pumpy climbing to a slab. Clip 3 bolts with the crux possibly clipping the second bolt. Then move up on increasingly positive holds placing finger-sized gear in a horizontal before moving onto the runout slab. There is another finger-sized piece of geat to be had (nut works well) left of the anchors to protect the last move or two before clipping the anchors.

Note - blowing any of the first 3 clips puts you at risk of groundfall. The third bolt has a good clipping stance, but the second bolt does not. If you aren't feeling it, bring a stickclip.
content.protection: 0.4 to #2 BD size cams, bolts, and chains.
content.location: As you walk along the rock, you ascend to an alcove with a big boulder to your left (river side/downhill). The bolts on the route can be seen above.

content.description: Clip the first bolt, then get through the crux to the second clip from a possibly tricky stance, then move on to a quick rest before hanging on till the top with generally positive holds.
content.protection: 5 bolts to anchors with lowering clips. It should go without saying, but please toprope off of your own gear, and use the anchors for the final lower off. All hardware is stainless.
content.location: Located in the back left of the small alcove on the right end of the cliff, it gets shade at about noon which can be a blessing on this sunny cliff.

content.description: Money is a great route and one of the best in this little area. Easy climbing gets you 1/3 of the way up. Get past the technical crux move, and then try to hang on to the shuts.
content.protection: 7 bolts and top anchors with clips. All hardware is stainless. Please use the clips for final loweroffs, never toproping.
content.location: About 100 yards along the wall just past a large, left-facing broken dihedral, there is a rock platform with 2 bolted routes ascending from it. This is the rightmost route.

content.description: Climb up a line of weakness on very positive holds to a high first bolt. Head up and left, then move back right a bit on good holds through the crux at bolt 4. Then cruise to the finish above the overhanging lip.
content.protection: Bolts to shuts. A nut or medium small cam might make some folks feel better further up the route in one easy section.
content.location: It is the first route on the cliff 20 feet prior to the spruce that makes the trail squeeze up against the cliff.

content.description: A hard start that is possibly a touch contrived takes you to some great, steep climbing on fun holds to a steep second crux at the anchors.
content.protection: 6 bolts to top anchors with clips. Please use the clips for final loweroffs, not toproping. Most hardware appears to be stainless.
content.location:
It is a ways down the wall. Look for a right-facing dihedral about 200 feet left of the big rock ledge under

Money

,

Cracky

, and

Lesser Grade

. Just right of the dihedral you will see two lines of bolts, this is the left line. It has two bolts closely spaced about 10-13 feet up.

content.description: This crack(ish) system protects fairly well and is an ok climb with solid rests every few moves.
content.protection: A single set of cams from 0.3 to 3 Camalot plus some medium nuts will be more than enough to sew it up. The anchor is SS glue-ins with Mussy hooks as of June 2020 thanks to San Luis Valley Climbers Alliance and ASCA.
content.location:
Start by clipping the first two bolts of

Money

then continue straight up via the shallow crack above.

content.description:
This is an inferior cousin to

Money

. It is easier higher up. A few bolts could have been placed better.
content.protection: 5 bolts to top anchors with Mussy hooks. All hardware replaced June 2020 with SS glue-ins thanks to San Luis Valley Climbers Alliance and ASCA.
content.location: It is the left of the two bolted lines off the flat rock ledge left of the large, left-facing dihedral.

content.description: This is a good beginner route or kid route.
content.location: It is immediately prior to the spruce tree that makes the trail squeeze against the rock.

content.description:
I would advise others not to climb this route. A number of the holds are huge, guillotine-like flakes that scared the crap out of me. Even though the initial climbing was easy, I stickclipped the first by and had my belayer stand well to the side. My belayer had to continue to shift position to stay out of the potential drop zone. The crux is not one you want to fall on due to bolt placement. Also, the rock quality is poorer than normal on this cliff.

The climb consists of moderate climbing through B3 with a 5.9ish move to clip B4. Then there is a pretty intriguing sequence to get to B5. Be careful as a fall in the crux will result in a pendulum and possibly the loss of some skin on the rock bulge near B4. The crux requires nailing a dyno to a hollow sidepull at B5 - unnerving. After that, it backs off to the anchors.

If you climb this and care about your belayer, make sure they are never below you. If one of the many large hollow holds rips, they will appreciate not being in the fall line.

I don't know the FA or the route name. I just wanted to propose something and warn folks.
content.location:
About 150 feet up river (West) from the nice rock ledge under

Money

, it is just a few feet right of

Hardly Certain

.
